section.name: MOD HEB LIT & CULT TRANS: THE CITY IN ISR LIT/FILM

comments:
This course examines cinematic and literary portrayals of childhood by Israelis and Europeans. Themes include conflicts, personal traumas, and nostalgia. Additionally, the course analyzes how film, poetry and prose use their respective languages to reconstruct the image of childhood; it discusses the authors’ and directors’ struggle to penetrate the psyche of a child and to retrieve fragments of past events, both personal and historical. There are five to six film screenings. 

All students showed a moderate concern for the general structure of the course. Many students stated that the class was too big for in-depth discussions and suggested having “too much to cover but not enough time to cover it” as the main reason. Although many students enjoyed all the assigned readings which were able to “really open [their] eyes to new ideas, concepts, and perspectives,” some students also thought that some of the readings did not seem to fit the course theme, but “were stretched to fit it.”

Professor Gold, according to students, was “able to stimulate interesting discussions, be incredibly informative, and also be incredibly entertaining” at the same time. Most students described her as “knowledgeable” and “spirited.” Students often stated that the professor “sometimes seemed to incorporate her own thoughts into discussions,” keeping students’ actual opinions from being heard in class discussions.

The content of this course changes from year to year. Therefore, students may take the class for credit more than once. This course was recommended for majors and non-majors alike.
